search.slidetext: title of the course: sleep disorders before we get started, let’s see how much you know about sleep. turn on your audio, enter your name and click on take quiz to put your knowledge to test. %enteryourname% take quiz take quiz take quiz take quiz take quiz take quiz title slide 1 / 23

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue pre – knowledge check q1 2 / 23 why do we sleep? select the response & click on the submit button below. a a no one knows no one knows no one knows b b to ensure proper functioning of our nervous system to ensure proper functioning of our nervous system to ensure proper functioning of our nervous system c c to clean the brain's memory slate to clean the brain's memory slate to clean the brain's memory slate d d to cool the brain to cool the brain to cool the brain

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue pre – knowledge check q2 3 / 23 what is sleep hygiene? select the response & click on the submit button below. a a a bath or shower before bed a bath or shower before bed a bath or shower before bed b b the promotion of regular sleep the promotion of regular sleep the promotion of regular sleep c c the practice of laundering bed linens the practice of laundering bed linens the practice of laundering bed linens d d avoiding emotion before bed avoiding emotion before bed avoiding emotion before bed

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue pre – knowledge check q3 4 / 23 what is true about sleep? select the response & click on the submit button below. (please select all that apply) a a sleep deprivation can trigger seizures in people with epilepsy. sleep deprivation can trigger seizures in people with epilepsy. sleep deprivation can trigger seizures in people with epilepsy. b b sleep problems occur in almost all people with mental disorders. sleep problems occur in almost all people with mental disorders. sleep problems occur in almost all people with mental disorders. c c extreme sleep deprivation can lead to hallucinations. extreme sleep deprivation can lead to hallucinations. extreme sleep deprivation can lead to hallucinations. d d all of the above all of the above all of the above
table of content 6 / 23 lesson 1 learning outcomes lesson 2 introduction lesson 3 meaning lesson 4 classification of sleep disorders lesson 5 sleeping positions lesson 6 food to be avioded
course objectives by the end of this course, you’ll be able to: define sleep classify sleep disorders examine insomnia & hypersomnia 7 / 23

introduction sleep is an important part of your daily routine—you spend about one-third of your time doing it. quality sleep – and getting enough of it at the right times -- is as essential to survival as food and water. without sleep you can’t form or maintain the pathways in your brain that let you learn and create new memories, and it’s harder to concentrate and respond quickly. 8 / 23

a sleep disorder is any condition that involves difficulty experienced when sleeping. such disorders often result in daytime fatigue, causing severe distress and impairment to work, and social or personal functioning. sleep disorders are extremely common in the general population and can lead to significant morbidity. sleep disorders may cause or exacerbate preexisting medical and psychiatric conditions and are associated with high rates of depression, anxiety, and impaired daytime functioning introduction 9 / 23

what is sleep? sleep is a complex biological process. while you are sleeping, you are unconscious, but your brain and body functions are still active. they are doing a number of important jobs that help you stay healthy and function at your best. so when you don't get enough quality sleep, it does more than just make you feel tired. it can affect your physical and mental health, thinking, and daily functioning. 10 / 23

a tingling or prickly sensation in your legs, along with a powerful urge to move them. a breathing disorder in which you stop breathing for 10 seconds or more during sleep being unable to fall asleep and stay asleep. this is the most common sleep disorder. sleep disorders click on each card to know more. insomnia insomnia sleep apnea sleep apnea restless leg syndrome (rls) restless leg syndrome (rls) 11 / 23

acting in unusual ways while falling asleep, sleeping, or waking from sleep, such as walking, talking, or eating. problems with the sleep-wake cycle. they make you unable to sleep and wake at the right times. being unable to stay awake during the day. this includes narcolepsy, which causes extreme daytime sleepiness. sleep disorders hypersomnia hypersomnia circadian rhythm disorders circadian rhythm disorders parasomnia parasomnia click on each card to know more. 12 / 23
most common sleeping positions what your sleeping position says about your mental health? click on each icon to reveal information. fetal soldier free fall left heron starfish right 13 / 32

most common sleeping positions fetal sleepers: warm & conscientious curling up in the fetal position like a newborn baby signals that you’re trying to comfort yourself. traits include a soft interior which is camouflaged by a tough exterior, shy but warm, conscientious, organized and ready to face the day. close close close close close close 14 / 23

most common sleeping positions back sleepers: high expectations sleeping on your back with your arms by your sides, also known as soldier position, reveals that you have high expectations of yourself and others, and practice personal responsibility. back sleepers are also the more likely to snore. close close close close close close 15 / 23

most common sleeping positions free fall sleepers: brash & anxious those who sleep on their stomachs with their arms wide are known as free fallers. you are likely to be brash and outgoing but also harbor feelings of anxiety due to feeling overwhelmed during your waking hours. close close close close close close 16 / 23

most common sleeping positions left side sleepers: creative and curious people who favor sleeping on their left sides are more likely to work in the literary and performing arts, marketing and advertising, and have a high level of education. close close close close close close 17 / 23

most common sleeping positions heron sleeper: unpredictable if you generally sleep with your arms and legs splayed, you're a heron sleeper. heron sleepers are moody, unpredictable, and have a hard time making decisions. close close close close close close 18 / 23

most common sleeping positions starfish sleepers: great friends if you sleep on your back with your arms wide, you're a starfish sleeper. starfish sleeper prefer not to be center of attention, and their keen listening skills make them trusted friends and confidants. close close close close close close 19 / 23

most common sleeping positions right side sleepers: risk and rewards right side sleepers were more likely to take risk. they are more likely to consume caffeine, gamble and challenge norms. right side sleepers are attracted to logistics, transportation, and entrepreneurial pursuits. close close close close close close 20 / 23 click on arrow to proceed next.
food to be avioded want some good sleep? then avoid the following food. coffee alcohol chocolate heavy food 21 / 23

incorrect you did not select the correct response. correct that's right! you selected the correct response. knowledge check 22 / 23 match the following: drag the numbers & drop it near to the appropriate sleep position then click on submit button below. fetal sleepers back sleepers free fall sleepers left side sleepers right side sleepers creative and curious warm & conscientious high expectations brash & anxious risk and rewards 1 1 1 2 2 2 3 3 3 4 4 4 5 5 5

knowledge check – result slide 23 / 23 fetal sleepers back sleepers free fall sleepers left side sleepers right side sleepers creative and curious warm & conscientious high expectations brash & anxious risk and rewards match the following: drag the numbers & drop it near to the appropriate sleep position then click on submit button below. 1 1 1 2 2 2 3 3 3 4 4 4 5 5 5

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Sleep is a complex biological process. While you are sleeping, you are unconscious, but your brain and body functions are still active. They are doing a number of important jobs that help you stay healthy and function at your best. So when you don't get enough quality sleep, it does more than just make you feel tired. It can affect your physical and mental health, thinking, and daily functioning." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
